Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Formal Language Theory in Linguistics: New Orleans, LA - January 2020

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will bring linguists and computer scientists together to discuss recent advances in Formal Language Theory and its relevance both to linguistic theory and to language technologies. Formal Language Theory (FLT) is a means to independently assess how a given attested or predicted linguistic pattern compares to other patterns in terms of the expressive power required to describe it. A grammar formalism with the expressive power to generate all the grammatical patterns found in the languages of the world without generating the non-occurring patterns would facilitate the comparison of different linguistic theories and allow precise claims to be made about the bounds of linguistic complexity. This workshop has two aims. The first is to take stock of existing work in FLT and its impact on theories of language and of its learnability, and to showcase new directions in which this work is headed. The second is to bring together linguists and computer scientists in order to establish deeper points of contact between their goals and methods as they relate to how both humans and machines can learn and use language, and to identify the most fruitful directions for moving forward. Because of the general nature of FLT, this research can also lead to practical applications broadly, from natural language processing and artificial intelligence to bioinformatics and information systems.

The workshop will take place during the third annual meeting of the Society for Computation in Linguistics (SCiL), which meets as a sister society at the annual meeting of the Linguistic Society of America (LSA). SCiL is designed to be a common meeting for research on the computational modeling of natural language from a variety of perspectives, particularly the theoretical linguistics and the natural language processing (NLP)/machine learning (ML) communities. The 2020 SCiL workshop on FLT in linguistics is particularly responsive to the society's mission as the formalisms that FLT research is based on are foundational to theoretical computer science. The workshop events will include a keynote address, a panel of three researchers, and two tutorials demonstrating some of the resources available for getting started on research in FLT in linguistics. There will also be mentoring sessions before, during, and after the workshop that pair young researchers interested in FLT/NLP/ML work with workshop participants, creating an opportunity to build an active network of young researchers as well as providing a venue for the organizers to receive feedback and assess the success of the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop on Formal Language Theory in Linguistics was held in conjunction with the Third Annual Meeting of the Society for Computation in Linguistics (SCiL) and brought together researchers from two largely disjoint scientific communities: linguistics and computer science. The grant supported tutorials, invited speakers, and a panel discussion featuring experts on formal language theory (FLT), as well as an abstract-reviewed poster session for work in progress. FLT is used by linguists as a way to identify precise restrictions on the range of possible patterns in human language and to understand how these can facilitate human learning of language. Computer scientists doing research in natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) are motivated by the similar goal of developing efficient learning algorithms capable of handling the complexity of data from natural language. Though their goals are related, interaction between linguists and NLP/ML researchers is limited. In bringing the two communities together through this workshop, each learned about recent advances in our understanding of complexity in natural language, and identified fruitful directions for moving forward.

The event was held under the auspices of the annual meeting of the Linguistics Society of America in New Orleans, LA, January 2-5, 2020, allowing for increased accessibility of the workshop to the broader linguistics community, and more specifically as part of SCiL?s annual meeting, which is a sister society of the LSA designed to bring together scientists who incorporate computational modeling of language into their research. As part of the Workshop in FLT, several events were spread throughout the four day conference, including tutorials for computational toolkits, invited speakers, and a special session with a panel of three women who are experts in FLT. Additionally, six short talks and posters featuring FLT research in progress were presented, offering young and less-experienced researchers an opportunity to present new ideas. On top of the invited speakers and tutorial instructors directly supported by grant funds, the workshop was well attended by members of the linguistics and computer science communities, with dozens of attendees present at each event, who benefitted from the training and networking opportunities offered as part of this NSF-funded initiative.

Research presented at the Workshop on Formal Language Theory in Linguistics is published in the open-access Proceedings of SCiL 2020, both with the ACL Anthology (https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/volumes/2020.scil-1/) and with Scholarworks (https://scholarworks.umass.edu/scil/). As of November 2020, the Scholarworks reader report indicates that papers from the SCiL 2020 proceedings have been downloaded over 27,000 times. This is an indication of the impact that these interdisciplinary research presentations are having within the fields of linguistics and computer science.
